reused_details.reused: The leaders of France, Spain and Portugal on Friday officially approved an ambitious underwater pipeline to bring green hydrogen from the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of Europe  The H2Med project, set to be completed by 2030 at a cost of about 2.5 billion ($2.6 billion), will help Europe make the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner energy.

Postmedia Network Inc. | 365 Bloor Street East, Toronto, Ontario, M4W 3L4 | 416-383-2300 Article content Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said the pipeline, dubbed H2Med, will be able to convey some 2 million metric tons of hydrogen to France annually  10% of the EU's estimated hydrogen needs.

French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.  It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen, he added.

He said that with the project, they aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.  Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.

reused_details.reused: The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).
reused_by_aic: The project is expected to cost 2.5 billion euros ($2.6 billion).

reused_details.reused: The announcement came after a meeting between Snchez, his French and Portuguese counterparts and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the eastern Spanish city of Alicante.

reused_by_aic: French President Emmanuel Macron said H2Med, which replaces an earlier proposal to transport gas across the Pyrenees Mountains, will take a new path through the Mediterranean and rely on a technology of the future, which is hydrogen.  It will also probably allow later other European interconnections toward some other countries which will want to get that hydrogen, he added.

He said that with the project, they aspire to be a benchmark not only in Europe, but also worldwide, in the field of hydrogen.  Spain and Portugal had initially wanted to pipe gas across land to France but Paris rejected that proposal.
